comments.text:
I would think that there is an implicit "so far as we know" at the end of 
the statement, as there is with any statement based on empirical data. 
 Everything psychological that we know of so far is indeed biological. 
 That doesn't mean we couldn't find, at some point in the future, that 
there is some psychological phenomenon that doesn't map to anything 
biological that we can detect.  That could happen, and if it does, most of 
neuroscience will have to be rewritten.  But so far, it hasn't happened.

Yes, we can't fully explain everything about consciousness in purely 
physical terms.  That's quite true.  But it's also true that every other 
proposed explanation has, so far, been able to explain EVEN LESS, if 
anything at all.
comments.author: Matthew Prorok

comments.text:
It *is* an oversimplified statement; I'd guess that "every psychological 
process (in animals) will be caused by a biological one" would probably 
reflect the most common stance of the psychological community better. I 
have yet to hear a dualist hypothesis with predictive and explanatory 
power. Until then, I'd keep the working hypothesis "brain causes mind". And 
there is clear evidence that altering the biochemistry of the brain causes 
changes in conscious experience - I suspect you are holding psychology to a 
higher standard than other sciences.
The data so far does not rule out philosophical debate, but so far this is 
the most successful approach in explaining the mind.

top_comment.text:
where does the first depolarization come from, for example that begins a 
thought, or the first firing when I decide to move my finger, either to the 
thought itself or the signal that starts in my brain and travels to my 
nueromuscular junction. Is this known?﻿
top_comment.author: grubbymanz

comments.text:
in terms of consciousness, i think the integrated information theory has 
some promise for providing the bridge i spoke of above, if you haven't 
checked it out. Interesting stuff!
comments.author: grubbymanz

comments.text:
no I am a strict materialist and reject dualism. I think the mind arises 
entirely from the brain, as does consciousness. I believe the phenomenon 
arises entirely from the physiological, but we just haven't found clear 
bridges yet. This is why I am asking the question tying will into an 
origination of action potentials (or at least a channeling of neural 
activity to send an efferent signal to the neuro-muscular junction), which 
takes a physiological occurence, neural depolarization- opening of voltage 
gated channels etc. I just don't think the description you provided is 
actually answering the question, not from a monoist perspective or anything 
else, not even in strict physiological terms.
comments.author: grubbymanz

comments.text:
I think you're right in characterizing your question as more philosophical 
than biological. What the answer boils down to would hinge on your 
understanding of consciousness, likely from some sort of monist or dualist 
stance. If you're asking from a monist point of view, then there can be no 
separation of willfully directed, conscious thoughts and/or decisions and 
their action potentials, because a decision—again, sticking with monism 
here—is a biological occurrence that is likely a series of action 
potentials which lead to the final efferent signal to direct your finger. 
But it seems that you are to some degree a dualist, which means you likely 
reject the conclusion that a decision or thought is in fact not a 
biological occurrence, but is rather phenomenological and, therefore, 
separate from biology entirely.

I don't disagree with you regardless of whether or not you are a monist or 
a dualist. But we cannot have a discussion on the mechanics and workings of 
thoughts and decisions and their biological processes unless we agree, 
foundationally, on whether or not we wish to support monism or dualism. 
Otherwise, our discussion will always remain at a standstill, as the 
fundamental principles surrounding or terms are necessarily mutually 
exclusive.

Because you knew the monist explanation from studying biology, then why ask 
"is this known"? Clearly, you know what a monist will answer, and you 
disagree with monism it seems. This also means that you likely know what a 
dualist will answer—the answer which you seem to support. So was your 
question just reaching for some sort of confirmation bias based response?
comments.author: Nick Denton

comments.text:
yeah I know all this from studying the nervous system in biology, but aside 
from reflex arcs and the classic, "hot stove leading one to move their 
finger, starting from nociceptors and maybe mechanoreceptors, your 
physiological description doesn't account for my phenomenological question. 
I'm asking about conscious decisions made apropos of nothing. like right 
now i'm gonna move my finger, there i did it. That had nothing to do with 
afferent signals from my finger. And I had to generate some corresponding 
series of action potentials, or at least channel them in some willful 
direction. Idk maybe this crosses into will and consciousness questions 
which are really in their nascent stage of finding viable answers.
comments.author: grubbymanz

comments.text:
Your brain is always active, and electrochemical signals are ever-present. 
That said, the somatic nervous system is responsible for voluntary bodily 
movement. Consider that a decision to move your finger is not the first 
signal sent to your finger; it is detecting heat, vibration, possibly pain, 
afferently sending stimuli information to the brain, terminating at the 
somatosensory cortex. This constant neuronal information allows you to fire 
neurons to send an efferent, contractile signal to the musculoskeletal 
system, allowing you to make fine movement of your finger, or whatever 
other body part you like. There really is no "first" depolarization, per 
se, since your brain is sending information to and/or receiving information 
from your finger constantly through your many senses (tactile perception, 
thermoception, vibrational perception, pressure perception, proprioception, 
and others!).
comments.author: Nick Denton

comments.text:
The mistake you are making is making a diagnosis based on sympthoms. 
Different conditions, with entirely different causes can result in very 
similar sympthoms. If you clasify conditions by sympthoms you'll mix things 
that should not be mixed.

Take the sympthoms for depression, for example, and label it a condition, 
now:

It can be a genetically predisposed condition, inhereted, that has nothing 
to do with the person's mind or family dynamics. In this case it would be a 
psychiatric condition, treatable only with antidepressives. Psychotherapy 
can help, but it won't cure anything, only make it less bad.

It can be a disfunctional adaptation of the mind to its enviornment. If 
this is the case it is a psychological condition, antidepressives will do 
more harm than good, and the person needs psychotherapy to get rid of it.

It can be part of the patient's family dynamics, in which case no ammount 
of psychotherapy or psychotropics will do a thing, unless the psychotherapy 
is aimed towars chainging the family dynamic (which would no longer be 
psychology, properly speaking, but family therapy through the individual) 
To fix this family therapy is needed.

It can also be a chemical imbalance caused by malnutrition, and in this 
case any of the above would be useless, and the solution would come from a 
nutriologist.

The sympthoms are the same in each case, but the source of the condition is 
very different. You have to identify conditions based on what they are, not 
how they look.

You are also assuming the patient has a single condition and a single 
problem, when this rarely the case.

For example, when a patient has a psychiatric condition, rest assured the 
mind of the patient will try to adapt to it, and very often this adaptation 
will result disfunctional. Aditionally it is posible that the family 
dynamics that will change to acomodate both those conditions will result 
pathological too. This makes 3 conditions, not 1, and if you treat it 
thinking it's just 1, you'll get nowhere.
comments.author: Sinclairelim

comments.text:
+Sinclairelim i agree that bipolar disorder is mainly a biological/physical 
problem. refer to my previous msg.
my point is that even in psychiatry, mental illnesses are thought to be 
caused by multiple factors: biology, psychology and social. these make up 
the biopsychosocial model. 
Besides the neurochemical imbalance(you have to be careful with this one. 
usually structural damage means something mechnical.) that we can obviously 
treat with lithium/ other mood stabilizers, there IS a psychodynamic 
explanation to bipolar disorder.that's why i asked you to go back and have 
a look in your karpan and sadock's sypnosis of psychiatry. if you're using 
the international student version it's on page 533.
same goes for major depression. you can argue that depression is merely 
caused by low levels of serotonin, but you have to be aware that there are 
many theories that explain how depression develops. plus cognitive therapy 
and psychodynamic therapy help in depression.

the take home message is that unless you are talking about ADHD, or autism, 
or dementia where it is clearly a biological disorder, it is wrong to say 
that there are no psychological components in functional disorders such as 
bipolar disorder and depression.
comments.author: 陳諾諾

comments.text:
I'm sure. Psychological problems are the result of a disfunctional 
adaptation of the mind to it's enviornment. The brain is working just fine 
in such problems, it's just not going in the right direction (as a way of 
speaking).

A person with bipolar disorder has a brain that is not working properly. 
The structure, for whatever reason, is damaged and requries external aid 
(drugs) to properly function. That makes it a psychiatric disorder, not a 
psychological one.

Maybe "structure" is the wrong word to convey the idea. English is not my 
first language so i have a bit of a problem there. I'll use an analogy 
instead: bipolar disorder is a hardware problem, not a software one. 
Psychology deals with software problems-

top_comment.text:
"Everything psychological is biological". I'm pretty sure most 
psychologists disagree with this. That's only a theory, people that support 
it are called biological psychologists. There's cognitive psychology, 
psychodynamic psychology, social psychology, behavioural psychology, 
evolutionary psychology amongst others. Biological psychology is only one 
perspective of many. Twin studies in disorders such as Anorexia Nervosa for 
example have cultural, age and sexuality differences and lack 100% 
concordance rates across monozygotic twins therefore other non-biological 
influences have influenced peoples psychology.

Biology is useful in explaining emotion, growth, biorhythms and homeostasis 
but cannot reliably explain lynch mobs, deindividuation, what music I 
listen to, what religion I believe in, it can't even properly explain 
disorders such as Anorexia Nervosa and Schizophrenia. Nor can it adequately 
explain the placebo or nocebo effect.

I'm a big fan of your videos because I'm lazy and I like learning stuff but 
that statement is theoretical, do not treat it as factual. I'm sure you're 
going to discuss other psychological perspectives in the future, the 
Stanford prison experiment is pretty big in psychology for example and is 
usually explained with social psychology. Please understand that although 
biology and psychology are linked, biology always influences psychology at 
least to some degree, but everything psychological is not yet proven to be 
caused by biology.﻿

comments.author: Miłosz Czernikowski

comments.text:
Adrenaline is made in the adrenal gland which is located just above your 
kidneys and is part of the endocrine system.

How your body knows when to produce adrenaline for say when you are walking 
down the street and suddenly you see a bear that escaped from the zoo my 
guess that your there was a response between your brain and pituitary gland 
located just off your brain stem which basically sends a chemical message, 
enzymes, hormones whatever you wish to call them to your adrenal glands to 
make a nice life-saving dose of  epinephrine so you can get as far away as 
possible, maybe leaping over a few fences to get a better displacement for 
distance traveled.

Even after the danger is over your heart continues to pump rapidly and you 
continue to also breathe rapidly because the epinephrine is still in your 
blood stream telling your those organs to work hard even if they don't know 
what they are working for.

As for your first question, it's all complicated for the past hour I have 
been looking online at just how your brain creates dopamine and from what I 
can tell that starts from the amino acid Phenylalanine being converted into 
Tyrosine by the enzyme Phenylalanine hydroxylase which as the name suggests 
hydroxylates Phenylalanine. Afterwards Tyrosine hydroxylase converts 
Tyrosine into Dihydroxyphenylalanine or L-DOPA which then depending on the 
cell is made into dopamine or into norepinephrine another neurotransmitter 
which sounds a lot the previously mentioned epinephrine because big shock 
that's where it comes from, just depends on the cell.

As too where all these amino acids come from, food, reduction, things like 
that. It is impossible for our brains to physically create the chemicals 
they would need to come from somewhere else or at least the resources for 
them would need to come from somewhere else and then they are constantly 
built and broken down and rebuilt and then cases like epinephrine they 
break apart so that they are no longer epinephrine which is a good thing 
because if it stayed that way forever then your heart would probably end up 
overworked and, you know, stop. The enzymes which do all the work of 
changing Phenylalanine to Tyrosine to L-DOPA to dopamine to norepinephrine 
to epinephrine are made in the cells (though some also come from food) and 
without them cellular activity would be impossible and it also shows again 
that what you get depends on the cell because if you want a certain 
chemical compound then you need the right enzyme to help change it.

Finally I am done, I read up A LOT so no TL;DR and anyone who wants to 
correct me, please do; I decided to do some research to figure out the 
answer to this question but my answer may have been false or misleading, 
but eh best intentions?

comments.text:
So a neuron can have many different transmitters, but not in the same 
synapse? This means that when the neuron "fire" there is a wide varriaty of 
trasmitters relesed to different receving neurons... or can several 
synapses connect to the same target neuron, but with different transmitters?
comments.author: Björn Vildljung

comments.text:
The way I learned it seems to suggest that there is only one kind of 
transmitter in one synapse, but I actually don't know for sure.
Neurons are often classified by one neurotransmitter (glutamic, GABAergic, 
cholinergic...). The transmitters are stored in little bubbles (vesicles). 
The electrical signal (action potential) coming down the axon causes 
calcium to flow in, which in turn makes the vesicles open up into the 
synaptic gap and release the transmitters inside. Since it is the action 
potential that triggers the transmitter release, and there is only one kind 
of action potential, it seems like the synapse cannot "decide" which 
transmitter to release.
Did that help you?

comments.text: +Nick Denton Awsome! this is the best EILI5 for this ive ever heard. thanks
comments.author: Cody Scott _

comments.text:
Exactly. When serotonin is released into the synaptic cleft, it's taken in 
by the postsynaptic neuron (that is, the "receiving" neuron). Mr. Green is 
right in saying that it's reuptaken into the first neuron, but it may also 
be kicked out of the cleft completely (diffused), or broken down by enzymes 
(deactivated). Either way, SSRIs block the first neuron's ability to 
reuptake the serotonin, which means that it hangs out in the cleft a lot 
longer, and is more likely to be used by the receiving neuron, thus 
allowing for more serotonin to be normally used, even when serotonin is 
relatively sparse.

captions.text:
Say it's late at night, you're home alone
drifting off to sleep, just, entering that

dream about Fritos, and then suddenly there's
a banging at the door! Suddenly you're wide

awake and it feels like your heart's gonna
explode. You jump up ready to run out the

back door, possibly grab a Phillips head screwdriver
and stab it into the darkness until it sticks

into something. Now whether it's a Weeping
Angel or your neighbor looking to borrow a

can of beans, it doesn't really matter because
when you heard that sudden noise, your startled

brain released an icy typhoon of chemicals.
And everything that's now going through your

mind, like your urge to flee, your urge to
defend yourself, that internal debate about

whether Weeping Angels are even real and "Woah!
Where's the cat?" All that? Is just a result
of those chemicals.

Our brains and our nervous systems and the
substances they produce and are always bathed

in are amazingly complex nuanced systems.
And even though we're always talking about

our mental activities being somehow separate
from all the biological stuff going on in

our bodies, in reality, the moods, ideas,
impulses, that flash through our minds are

spurred by our biological condition. As psychologists
like to say, "Everything psychological is

biological." So one way to understand how
your mind works is to look at how the chemistry

of your body influences how you think, sense,
and feel about the world around you. To do

that, we begin at the simplest level, the
system with the smallest parts, it's all about
the neuron, baby.
[Intro]

Neurons, or nerve cells, are the building
blocks that comprise our nervous systems.

Neurons share the same basic makeup as our
other cells, but they have electrochemical

mojo that lets them transmit messages to each
other. Your brain alone is made up of billions

of neurons, and to understand why we think
or dream or do anything, you gotta first understand

how these little transmitters work. You actually
have several different types of neurons in

your body, from ones that are less than a
millimeter long in your brain to ones that

run the whole length of your leg! Yes, you
have cells as long as your legs, which is

nothing compared to the hundred and fifty
feet the nerve cells of some dinosaurs had
to be, I'm getting off topic, sorry.

No matter how big a nerve is, they all have
the same three basic parts: the soma, dendrites,

and axon. The soma, or cell body, is basically
the neuron's life support; it contains all

that necessary cell action like the nucleus,
DNA, mitochondria, ribosomes, and such. So,

if the soma dies, the whole neuron goes with
it. The dendrites, as bushy and branch-like

as the trees they're named after, receive
messages and gossip from other cells. They're

the listeners, whispering what they hear back
to the soma. The axon is the talker. This

long, cable-like extension transmits electrical
impulses from the cell body out to other neurons

or glands or muscles. Whereas the dendrites
are short and bushy, the axon fiber is long,

and, depending on what type of neuron it is,
is sometimes encased in a protective layer

of fatty tissue, called the myelin sheath.
It's almost like an insulated electrical wire,

the myelin sheath speeds up the transmission
of messages, and if it degrades, as it does

with those affected with multiple sclerosis,
those signals are degraded as well, eventually
leading to lack of muscle control.

Neurons transmit signals either when stimulated
by sensory input or triggered by neighboring

neurons. The dendrites pick up the signal
and activate the neuron's action potential,

or firing impulse, that shoots an electrical
charge down the axon to its terminals and

towards the neighboring neurons. The contact
points between neurons are called synapses.

All those bushy little dendrites are decorated
with synapses that almost but don't quite

touch the neighboring axon in the tiniest
game of "I'm not touching you!" of all time.

They're less than a millionth of an inch apart.
And that microscopic cleft is called the synaptic

gap. So, when an action potential runs down
to the end of an axon, it activates the chemical

messengers that jump that tiny synaptic gap,
flying like that little air kiss and landing

on the receptor sites of the receiving neuron.
Those messengers are neurotransmitters.

Although neurotransmitters slide right into
their intended receptors like a key into a

lock, they don't stay bonded to the receiving
neuron. They just sort of pop out, having

excited or inhibited the receiving neuron's
trigger, then the extras immediately get reabsorbed

by the neuron that released them in the first
place in a process called reuptake. Kinda

like, "Here you go, oh, psych!" So neurons
communicate with neurotransmitters which in

turn cause motion and emotion; they help us
move around, make jazz hands, learn, feel,

remember, stay alert, get sleepy, and pretty
much do everything we do.

Some of them just make you feel good, like
the endorphins we get flooded with after running

ten miles or falling in love or eating a really
good piece of pie. We've got over 100 different

kinds of these brilliant neurotransmitters
-- some are excitatory and others are inhibitory,

and all are good reminders that everything
psychological is also biological. Excitatory

neurotransmitters rev up the neuron, increasing
the chances it will fire off an action potential.

Norepinephrine is one you're probably familiar
with, it helps control alertness and arousal.

Glutamate is another, involved in memory,
but an over-supply of it can wig out the brain

and cause seizures and migraines which is
why some people are sensitive to all that

MSG, or monosodium glutamate, in their Ramen.
Inhibitory neurotransmitters on the other

hand, chill neurons out, decreasing the likelihood
that the neuron will jump into action. GABA–

gamma-aminobutyric acid– is a major inhibitory
neurotransmitter, and you've probably heard

of serotonin which affects your mood and hunger
and sleep. Low amounts of serotonin are linked

to depression, and a certain class of antidepressants
help raise serotonin levels in the brain.

Some neurotransmitters like acetylcholine
and dopamine play both sides and can both

excite or inhibit neurons depending on what
type of receptors they encounter. Acetylcholine

enables muscle action and influences learning
and memory; Alzheimer's patients experience

a deterioration of their acetylcholine producing
neurons. Dopamine, meanwhile, is associated

with learning, movement, and pleasurable emotions,
and excessive amounts of it are linked to

schizophrenia as well as addictive and impulsive
behavior.

So neurotransmitters are basically your nervous
system's couriers. But they aren't the only

chemical messengers delivering the news; they've
got some competition brewing in the endocrine

system. And if you've been through puberty,
you know what I'm talking about: hormones.

Like neurotransmitters, hormones act on the
brain, and indeed some of them are chemically

identical to certain neurotransmitters. Hormones
affect our moods, arousal, and circadian rhythm,

they regulate our metabolism, monitor our
immune system, signal growth, and help with

sexual reproduction. You could say that most
of them boil down to the basics: attraction,
appetite, and aggression.

Whereas neurons and synapses flick on and
off, sending messages with amazing speed,

the endocrine system likes to take its time,
delivering the body's slow chemical communications

through a set of glands that secrete hormones
into the bloodstream where they're ferried
to other tissues, especially the brain.

So while the nervous and endocrine systems
are similar, in that they both produce chemicals

destined to hit up certain receptors, they
operate at very different speeds. It's like,

if the nervous system wants to get in touch
